schema.name: mAdminState
schema.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
schema.label: Enable administrative state
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>
A descriptive summary for the configuration.
schema.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
schema.name: UserSummary
IPConfigMode
schema.summary: Set the configuration mode for the interface.

value.name: static
value.description: The configuration is static. Manually define the required properties.

value.name: dhcp
value.description: The configuration uses IPv4 autoconfiguration with DHCP.

value.name: slaac
value.description: The configuration uses IPv6 autoconfiguration with SLAAC.

schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the configuration mode for the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.</p><ul><li>With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface.</li><li>With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li><li>With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>The configuration mode of the interface. Although you can set multiple modes, only one mode is supported.</p><ul><li>With static configuration, you must define the configuration for the physical interface. <ul><li>Assign the primary network address.</li><li>Manage secondary, or auxiliary, network addresses.</li><li>Assign the default IPv4 gateway.</li><li>Assign the default IPv6 gateway, if you define IPv6 IP addresses.</li><li>Manage static routes in the routing table.</li></ul></li><li>With DHCP autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li><li>With SLAAC autoconfiguration, the appliance ignores configuration data about the physical interface.</li></ul>

schema.name: IPAddress
schema.summary: Set the primary IP address and netmask.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>The IP address and netmask of the primary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>

schema.name: DefaultGateway
schema.summary: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.
schema.description: The IPv4 address for the default IPv4 gateway. All IPv4 network addresses use this gateway.

schema.name: DefaultIPv6Gateway
schema.summary: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway.
schema.description: The IPv6 address for the default IPv6 gateway. All IPv6 network addresses use this gateway. If you do not use IPv6 network addresses, do not define this property.

schema.name: SecondaryAddress
schema.summary: Set secondary IP addresses and netmasks.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the IP address and netmask of the secondary IP address. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>The IP addresses and netmasks of secondary IP addresses. Specify the netmask with CIDR notation.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>

schema.name: StaticRoutes
schema.summary: Manage the static routes in the routing table.

property.description: <p>Specify the IP address and netmask for each destination network address. The netmask is in CIDR format is the integer that specifies the prefix length.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 32.</li><li>For IPv6, the prefix length can be in the range 0 - 128.</li></ul>
property.name: Destination

property.description: Specify the IP address of the next-hop router.
property.name: Gateway
Metric
property.description: <p>Optionally specify the preference for the route. The lesser the value, the greater the preference. For each IP family, the supported range differs.</p><ul><li>For IPv4, enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 0.</li><li>For IPv6, enter a value in the range 0 - 65536. The default value is 512.</li></ul>

schema.hoverhelp: Manage the static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network.
schema.description: The static routes in the routing table. Add a static route to a remote IP prefix through a router connected to this network. When the appliance connects to a remote address, the static route with the longest prefix match is used. If multiple routes have the same prefix match, the static route with the lowest metric is used. If the metric is the same, the static route is chosen randomly.

schema.name: DADTransmits
schema.summary: Set the number of IPv6 duplication address detection attempts.
schema.description: The number of IPv6 duplication address detection (DAD) attempts. The default value is 1.

schema.name: DADRetransmitTimer
schema.summary: Set the delay between IPv6 neighbor discovery (ND) attempts.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.
schema.description: The delay between IPv6 Neighbor Discovery (ND) attempts. The default value is 1000. This property affects duplication address detection (DAD) and other ND operations.

schema.name: StandbyControl
schema.summary: Indicate whether to allow a standby configuration.
schema.description: <p>Whether to allow a standby configuration. The standby configuration defines the policies for the group that this interface is a member. A standby group is the collection of interfaces on different appliances in the multicast domain that share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. When at least one member of a standby group can reach the multicast domain, the virtual IP group receives the traffic.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

schema.name: Group
schema.summary: Set the number of the standby group in the multicast domain.
schema.description: <p>The number of the standby group in a multicast domain. The multicast domain is a group of interfaces that receive traffic from each other on the IP address 224.0.0.2 (the all-routers IP multicast group). If the multicast domain becomes partitioned, which is an unusual situation, a member in each partition becomes the active member to handle connections in its partition.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not use a group number that conflicts with the number of an existing standby group or any network group that uses Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP).</p><p>The interfaces of a standby group are on the same network segment and share the responsibility for one virtual IP address. Interfaces in the standby group require the following configuration.</p><ul><li>Belong to the same group.</li><li>Use the same primary virtual IP address.</li><li>Use the same authentication, or security token.</li></ul>

schema.name: VirtualIP
schema.summary: Set the primary virtual IP address of standby group.
schema.description: <p>The primary virtual IP address of the standby group. The active member of the standby group uses this IP address. All interfaces in the standby group must use the same virtual IP address. External clients that contact the active member of the standby group should use this IP address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

schema.name: SecondaryVirtualIP
schema.summary: Manage secondary virtual IP addresses that follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface.
schema.description: <p>Auxiliary, or secondary, virtual IP addresses to the standby configuration. Secondary addresses follow the active virtual IP address to the active interface. Secondary addresses are on the same interface as the primary address and are enabled and disabled in coordination with the primary address.</p><p><b>Attention:</b> Virtual IP addresses in a standby configuration must be IPv4 addresses.</p>

schema.name: Preempt
schema.summary: Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to support preemption in the standby group. <b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>
schema.description: <p>Whether to support preemption in the standby configuration for the initially active interface. Depending on the preemption setting, the follow activity occurs when the initially active member returns to service after a failure.</p><ul><li>When preemption is enabled, the interface resumes its active role. The standby interface becomes a passive member.</li><li>When preemption is disabled, the interface is a passive member.</li></ul><p><b>Attention:</b> Do not enable preemption.</p>

schema.name: Priority
schema.summary: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.
schema.description: <p>The priority of the interface in the standby group. Enter a value in the range 0 - 255. The default value is 100. Use the default value unless one system or interface is in some way better than another one.</p><p>For each standby group, there is one active member and one or more passive members. The interface with the highest priority seeks to be the active member. If multiple interfaces have the same priority, one becomes the active member.</p>

schema.name: SelfBalance
schema.summary: Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Indicates whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>Whether to use self-balancing in the standby group.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the active member distributes connections to available members.</li><li>When disabled, all connections go to the active member. The active member receives all TCP connections and processes all requests and responses. If the active member becomes unavailable, the standby member becomes the active members.</li></ul><p>The active member manages all TCP connections to virtual IP addresses. When a client initiates a new TCP connection, the active member selects a member to act as the connection endpoint. The active member tracks member capabilities to distribute traffic appropriately. The selected member completes the establishment of the connection. The active member forwards all segments of the TCP connection to the member that is acting as the connection endpoint.</p><ul><li>In a non-graceful transition, if the active member becomes unavailable, the passive member with the next highest priority becomes the active member. The active member might become unavailable because of network issues, an appliance crash, power outage, or similar cause.</li><li>In a graceful transition, such as for scheduled maintenance, most connections can be preserved if the appliance that terminates the connection remains available. In practice, quiesce the active appliance to ensure that established connections complete before you start maintenance; for example, apply firmware. In some environments, the time for the takeover exceeds the client timeout value. Similarly, if the appliance timeout value is aggressive, connections can be lost because the appliance terminated the connection because of a timeout.</li></ul>

schema.name: Authentication
schema.summary: Set the authentication string for the interface in the standby group.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the authentication string, or security token in hex. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.
schema.description: The authentication string, or security token in hex. The default value is 0x5841333500000000. Every member in the standby group must use the same security token.

schema.name: HelloTimer
schema.summary: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages
schema.hoverhelp: Set the frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40.
schema.description: The frequency to broadcast hello messages. Set this value to at least one third the duration of the hold timer. Enter a value in the range 2 - 40. The default value is 3.

schema.name: HoldTimer
schema.summary: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120.
schema.description: The duration to wait before the standby member attempts a failover. Set this value to at least three times the interval of hello messages. Enter a value in the range 6 - 120. The default value is 10.

schema.name: DistAlg
schema.summary: Set the distribution algorithm for incoming connections when self-balancing is enabled.

value.name: wlc
value.description: The weighted least connection algorithm uses an internal CPU-based weight with the number of current connections to each member to distribute incoming connections among available member. A member receives a new connection that is based on a combination of its weight (or preference) and its number of active connections. The algorithm attempts to balance the connection completion rate across members so that each member has the same number of active connections.

value.name: rr
value.description: The round robin algorithm maintains a list of members and evenly distributes incoming connections among available members. The algorithm attempts to balance the incoming connection rate across members.

schema.description: The algorithm to distribute incoming connections to available members when self-balancing is enabled.

value.summary: Indicates that the parent is an Ethernet interface.
value.name: ethernet
value.description: The parent is an Ethernet interface.

value.summary: Indicates that the parent is a link aggregation interface.
value.name: link-aggregation
value.description: The parent is a link aggregation interface.

schema.name: OverType
schema.summary: Set the parent interface type.
schema.description: The parent interface type for the VLAN interface.

schema.name: EthernetInterface
schema.summary: Set the parent Ethernet interface.
schema.description: The parent Ethernet interface for the VLAN interface.

schema.name: LinkAggInterface
schema.summary: Set the parent link aggregation interface.
schema.description: The parent link aggregation interface for the VLAN interface.

schema.name: Identifier
schema.summary: Set the unique VLAN identifier.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the VLAN identifier that is unique among all VLAN interfaces on the same Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 1 - 4094.
schema.description: The unique VLAN identifier to send and receive traffic. The identifier must be unique among all VLAN interfaces on the same Ethernet interface. Enter a value in the range 1 - 4094. The default value is 2.

schema.name: DefaultOutboundPriority
schema.summary: Set the priority for outbound packets.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the priority value for outbound VLAN headers for packets. These packets are sent on this VLAN interface. This value is placed in the <tt>user_control</tt> field of the Tag Control Information (TCI). Enter a value in the range 0 - 7.</p>
schema.description: <p>The priority value for outbound VLAN headers for packets. These packets are sent on this VLAN interface. This value is placed in the <tt>user_control</tt> field of the Tag Control Information (TCI). The exact interpretation of the value depends on the VLAN switch configuration. Enter a value in the range 0 - 7. The default value is 0.</p>

schema.name: MTU
schema.summary: Set the maximum transmission unit for the VLAN interface.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the maximum transmission unit for the VLAN interface. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128.
schema.description: The maximum transmission unit (MTU) for the VLAN interface. The MTU for the VLAN interface cannot be greater than the MTU of the parent interface. The MTU is determined regardless of the length of the layer 2 encapsulation. Enter a value in the range 576 - 16128. The default value is 1500.

schema.name: HardwareOffload
schema.summary: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware.
schema.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing to hardware. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.
schema.description: <p>Whether to offload TCP/IP packet processing. By default, offloading is enabled.</p><ul><li>When enabled, offloads TCP/IP packet processing of VLAN device drivers and chips. Hardware offload can improve performance.</li><li>When disabled, does not offload TCP/IP packet processing. Disable this option only when IBM Support diagnoses that you are encountering a problem.</li></ul><p>If you disable the hardware offload and then re-enable offloading, you must restart the appliance for the change to take effect.</p>
